text:
Situation A. Theories on Theoretical Probabilities

Angela’s group made some claims about drawing the chips in the Initial Challenge. Do you agree with the claims? Explain.

Claim 1

The sum of the probabilities is 1

P(red or blue or yellow) = P(red) + P(blue) + P(yellow) = 1

Claim 2

The sum of the probability of drawing a blue chip and the probability of not drawing a blue chip is 1.

P(blue or not blue) = P(blue) + P(not blue) = 1

True, if you are considering the possibilities of what is in the container.

P(blue) = 6/18;

P(not blue) or P(red or yellow) = 12/18.

6/18 + 12/18 = 18/18 or 1.

Claim 3

The probability of drawing either a red or a yellow chip is the sum of the probabilities of drawing a red chip and drawing a yellow chip.

P(red or yellow) = P(red) + P(yellow)

Claim 4

The probability of drawing any color other than red, yellow, or blue is 0.

P(not red, not yellow, or not blue) = 0

Correct.

The probability of drawing a red is 9/18 and the probability of drawing a yellow is 3/18, so theoretically 12/18 of the time you will get red or yellow.

Another way to look at it is with the counterargument that 6/18 of the time you will get blue so 1 - (6/18) = 12/18.

True.

It is impossible to get a chip that is not red, yellow, or blue. So the probability is 0.

Note: These claims represent a special rule of addition for probability. The events are mutually exclusive. That is, there is no overlap in choosing a color.

So P(red or blue or yellow) = P(red) + P(blue) + P(yellow).

The general addition rule for probability subtracts the probability of both events occurring:

P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A and B).

Situation B. Drawing Blocks - Theoretical Probabilities

Ms. Tsao’s Class Conjecture

We think the sum of the theoretical probabilities for an event is always 1.

Ms. Tsao suggests they test their conjecture on another experiment.

Experiment:

A bucket contains

  • two yellow blocks,
  • four blue blocks, and
  • six red blocks.

The blocks are all the same size. A player chooses a block from the bucket at random.
• What is the theoretical probability the block is yellow? Blue? Red? Which color is most likely to be drawn?

P(Yellow) = 2/12 or 1/6

P(Blue) = 4/12 or 1/3

P(Red) = 6/12 or 1/2

Red is most likely to be drawn.
• What is the sum of the probabilities? Does it agree with the conjecture?
Yes. It makes sense that the sum of the probabilities is 1. You would want to account for all of the possible outcomes. So all the parts should equal the whole in the ratios.

Situation C. Rodney's Conjectures

Rodney’s group made some conjectures about drawing blocks in Situation B. Are their conjectures correct? Explain why.

Conjecture 1

If we add 2 blue blocks to the bucket, then the probability of drawing a blue block is 1/2.

Incorrect.

There would now by 14 blocks, and 6 would be blue. P(blue) is 6/14.

6/14 ≠ 1/2

Conjecture 2

Jakayla says the probability of drawing a blue is 12/4

Incorrect.

The correct probability for drawing a blue is 4/12 or 1/3. The number of favorable events can never be greater than the total number of events, so a probability can never be greater than 1 (although a probability can be equal to 1).

Conjecture 3

If we triple the number of each color, the probability of drawing each color is the same as adding 3 of each color.

Incorrect.

When you triple the amount of each color, the ratios remain equivalent.

P(yellow) = 6/36 or 1/6

P(blue) = 12/36 or 1/3

P(red) = 18/36 or 1/2

When you add 3 more of each color, the ratios change and are not equivalent.

P(yellow) = 5/21

P(blue) = 7/21 or 1/3

P(red) = 9/21 or 3/7

Note: Probabilities are ratios, so they have multiplicative relationships, not additive relationships.

Situation D. A Bag of Marbles

Mr. Tsao suggests one more experiment. A bag contains several marbles. Each marble is red or white or blue. The P(red = 1/3, and P(white) = 1/6.

  1. What is the probability of choosing a blue marble? Explain.
  2. What is the least number of marbles that can be in the bag?
  3. Suppose the bag contains the least number of marbles. How many of each color does the bag contain?
  4. Can the bag contain 48 marbles? If so, how many of each color does it contain?
  5. Suppose the bag contains 8 red marbles and 4 white marbles. How many blue marbles does it contain?

1. P(blue) = 3/6. Total probability is 1. P(red or white) = 1/6 + 1/3 = 3/6, so P(blue) = 1 - 3/6 = 3/6.
  2. 6 marbles: 1 white, 2 red, 3 blue
  3. 1 white, 2 red, 3 blue
  4. Yes. 8 white, 16 red, 24 blue.
  5. 12
